Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: A Smartphone-Based Pathogen Detection Device for Remote and Low-Resource Settings
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to enable a consumer device for the detection of infectious pathogens at the point-of-need instead of in a central laboratory environment. The project will enhance current approaches to disease detection and monitoring in remote and low-resource settings by rapid and sensitive detection of infectious agents and automated data-logging. The commercial impact of the detection system leverages current smartphone capability in concert with advances in imaging, microfluidics, and enhanced computation to deliver detection of multiple important human pathogens all within a portable format. Further, widespread user experience with smartphone technologies mitigates the need for additional training steps and lowers barriers to adoption. This project will support extensive customer discovery with field workers, healthcare community workers, clinicians, nurses, and procurement officials within governmental and aid organizations.

This I-Corps project integrates the smartphone with external hardware and disposable microfluidic chips to enable a portable pathogen detection platform. The intellectual merit of the project stems from the implementation of newly developed particle diffusometry technology, an optical-based method that quantifies the Brownian motion of particles within a fluid. Combining particle diffusometry with nucleic acid-based DNA amplification methods that are standard for point-of-care device industry allows for order of magnitude increases in the sensitivity of pathogen detection. In the presence of pathogens, DNA amplification occurs and causes a decrease in the motion of particles in the sample solution that is imaged by the smartphone camera/external hardware microscope lens system. A smartphone application performs all of the quantitative computation, providing both detection results and immediately logging the data. Data can be readily pushed to the cloud where organizations can track detection events in real-time. Therefore, this I-Corps project will explore the market potential for smartphone-based pathogen detection in remote and low-resource settings and for applications where disease surveillance and monitoring is of great utility. To this end, this project will provide fast and affordable infectious pathogen detection solutions while aiding in effective healthcare resource distribution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our experience with the NSF-ICORPS Teams program was life changing. During the 7-week intensive program and beyond, the entrepreneurial skills that we learned through the Lean Launchpad framework has helped us hone our business plan, understand our customer needs, and pivot to find our first minimal viable product. During the 7 week I-Corps program April ? June 2018 we interview 110 potential customers and identified our value proposition, clarified our business model, defined our key stakeholders, mapped our business ecosystem, and identified the specific product distribution channels. 

Our goals during the program were to: 1) To validate our customer segment throughout the United States and in a few targeted lower-resource settings such as Haiti, and Uganda or Kenya; 2) To understand the critical needs of our customers and to identify and develop relationships with key partners for manufacturing and distribution; 3) To establish and strengthen key implementation partnerships. Through the I-CORPs Lean Launchpad methods and travel support we were able to successfully accomplish all of these goals.  1) We have traveled across the US and to Haiti and Kenya talking to key stakeholders at local environmental and health agencies and non-governmental organizations. 2) We identified critical needs in point-of-needs testing.  Our product would not be used at the household or bedside for individual use, but agencies that monitor water quality are very interested in the rapid detection and ability to use GPS data to pinpoint contaminated water sources. 3) We have established key partnerships for manufacturing. We worked with a microfluidics chip manufacturer to develop prototypes of our disposable, one-time use cartridge. We furthered our partnership with the University of Florida?s Emerging Pathogen Institute and their lab in Gressier, Haiti and established a partnershis with non-governmental organizations in Kenya.

Moving forward we are continuing to focus on developing key partnerships so that our product can be tested in the field. This will enable us to refine our solution and develop customers within the global health realm. For example, we our partnership with University of Florida?s Emerging Pathogens Institute (UF-EPI) in Gressier, Haiti. UF-EPI is one of the few organizations working in Haiti that routinely test for cholera in water sources. This will help us better understand user needs and improve the design characteristics and functionality of our solution. We have also recently established a partnership with the International Centre for Diarroheal Disease Research, Bangladesh (ICDDR,B) in Dhaka, the only diarrhoeal hospital in world, which treats 220,000 patients a year. They are also involved in water quality monitoring and research and have partnered with us to test our devices in the field. The future looks bright for OmniVis as we continue our calling to reduce the number of cholera cases worldwide.
